item.title: 1. Microeconomics: Introduction and Supply and Demand
item.description:
Based on 1. Introduction and Supply & Demand by MIT OpenCourseWare

click the audio icon to hear a section on youtube ðŸ”‰

Introduction

This lecture is the first in a microeconomics course taught by Professor John Gruber. The lecture covers course details, the essence of microeconomics, and a foundational concept - supply and demand.

Course Details

  • The course will have a distinct policy angle, emphasizing the role of government policy in economics. ðŸ”‰
  • A separate course, 1441, delves deeper into economic policy.
  • The professor encourages active participation and questions, emphasizing the importance of understanding concepts rather than memorizing notes.

What is Microeconomics?

  • Microeconomics is the study of how individuals and firms make decisions in a world of scarcity. ðŸ”‰
  • It is essentially a series of constrained optimization exercises where economic agents strive to make themselves as well off as possible given their constraints. ðŸ”‰
  • The course focuses on trade-offs and the concept of opportunity cost. ðŸ”‰

  • “Every action or every inaction has a cost, and that you could have been doing something else instead.” ðŸ”‰

item.title: 2. Microeconomics: Preferences and Utility Functions
item.description:
Based on 2. Preferences and Utility Functions by MIT OpenCourseWare

click the audio icon to hear a section on youtube ðŸ”‰

Introduction

This lecture delves into the foundation of the demand curve, exploring how consumer preferences and budget constraints shape choices. The main focus is on understanding utility maximization, a core concept in economics.

Consumer Preferences and Utility Functions ðŸ”‰

  • The demand curve arises from consumer decision-making, which can be modeled as utility maximization. ðŸ”‰
  • Utility maximization is the process of making choices that maximize satisfaction given constraints. ðŸ”‰
  • Consumer preferences represent what people want, while budget constraints represent what they can afford. ðŸ”‰
  • The lecture will focus on preferences and their mathematical representation through utility functions. ðŸ”‰
  • The assumption of completeness means that consumers can always rank their preferences, even if they are indifferent between some options.
  • Transitivity assumes that if you prefer A to B and B to C, then you prefer A to C. ðŸ”‰
  • Non-satiation, or more is better, is a core economic assumption that implies consumers always prefer more to less. ðŸ”‰

Graphical Representation of Preferences: Indifference Curves ðŸ”‰

item.title: 3. Microeconomics: Consumer Choice with Budget Constraints
item.description:
Based on 1. Consumer Choice with Budget Constraints by MIT OpenCourseWare

click the audio icon to hear a section on youtube ðŸ”‰

Introduction

This lecture continues the discussion on consumer choice, focusing on how budget constraints affect choices. The lecture covers the construction of budget constraints, how consumers make choices within constraints, and a real-world example of food stamps.

Budget Constraints

Summary: Budget constraints represent the limited resources available to consumers, forcing them to make choices. The lecture assumes income equals spending, neglecting savings or borrowing, which is a reasonable approximation for most Americans.

item.title: 4. Microeconomics: Consumer Choice - Deriving Demand Curves and Elasticity
item.description:
Based on 4. Consumer Choice: Deriving Demand Curves and Elasticity by MIT OpenCourseWare

click the audio icon to hear a section on youtube ðŸ”‰

Introduction

This lecture continues the discussion of consumer choice by deriving the demand curve and exploring the concept of elasticity of demand. We will see how, using the tools learned so far, we can explain the downward-sloping relationship between price and quantity demanded. We will also examine how changes in income and price affect demand.

Introduction:

This lecture revisits the concept of consumer choice, focusing on deriving the demand curve and exploring the elasticity of demand. The lecture delves into how changes in income and price affect demand.
